summary.text_en: Galileo observed the sky with his homemade telescope, discovering Jupiter's 4 moons, mountains on the Moon, and Venus's phasesâ€”observations directly proving Copernicus's heliocentrism.
key_points_en: Observed mountains and craters on Moon

story.text_en: In 1609, hearing the Dutch invented the telescope, Galileo made one with 20Ã— magnification. He pointed it at the sky, seeing unprecedented sights: the Moon wasn't a smooth sphere but had mountains and craters! Jupiter had 4 small stars orbiting it. These discoveries shocked the world but led to his house arrest by the Church.

fun_facts.text_en: Galileo's telescope only magnified 20Ã—, but he saw what others couldn't!
Legend says he whispered in court: 'And yet it moves!' (Eppur si muove)
He was under house arrest until death, but secretly continued research and wrote important works.

experiment.description_en: Combine a large magnifying glass (objective) and small one (eyepiece) to make a simple telescope! Try observing distant buildings or the Moon.
experiment.why_en: Objective collects light forming image, eyepiece magnifies this image for clearer view.

simple_explanation.text_en: Galileo made a super powerful telescope, letting humans see Moon, Jupiter, and stars clearly for the first time! He found Moon isn't smooth, Jupiter has its own 'little moons'.

impact.text_en: Galileo's observations provided direct evidence for heliocentrism, inaugurating telescopic astronomy. His scientific method (observation-experiment-mathematics) became foundation of modern science.

influenced.contribution_en: Observational data helped Kepler refine planetary laws

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Galileo used telescope to confirm Copernicus's heliocentrism. His observational methods and data helped Kepler discover planetary motion laws. Newton later said: 'If I have seen further, it is by standing on shoulders of giants'â€”Galileo was one of those giants.
